div.sent: Water is a compound.
Two volumes of hydrogen combine chemically with one volume of oxygen to form water.
Water is found in plenty in nature.
The three fourth of the earth surface contains water and one part land.
Water can be found in nature in three states solid, liquid and gas.
In this chapter we shall discuss about a special characteristic of water i.e. hardness of water.
Rain water: Rain water is the purest of all natural water.
Water changes to steam on the rivers, canals, ponds, lakes, oceans, etc. by the heat of the sun.
This steam condenses into cloud and then produces rain for the earth.
During the rain, nitrogen, oxygen, ammonia, carbon dioxide, nitric acid, dust particles of the air, bacteria, etc. are dissolved in rain water.
So water from the initial stage of the rain is not pure.
Water collected after a long time since the raining started is comparatively pure.
Rain water is most essential for the life of all plants and animals.
It is also very useful for agriculture.
The rain water after falling on the earth surface penetrates through the pores of various solid substances of the earth e.g.
soil, sand, stone, etc. Down the earth, it finally reaches a stage when it cannot go down any further.
Clay, granite, slate, etc are contained in this impenetrable layer.
Water begins to collect on this impenetrable layer and finally comes out as fountain water.
This fountain water contains dissolved minerals, viz.
sodium, potassium, magnesium, carbon dioxide, hydrogen sulphide, etc. Due to this, fountain water is called mineral water too.
River water: Rain water mainly runs into the river.
Rain water, fountain water and water from the melted ice flow on the earth's surface and then fall into the river.
Rain water, while passing through the soil, mix up with various kinds of organic and inorganic, dissolved and suspended impurities.
Chlorides, sulphates and carbonates of sodium, potassium, calcium and iron are mixed with the river water.
Moreover river water bears bacteria.
Sea water: River water falls finally into the sea.
It contains many suspended impurities.
Sea water contains chlorides, bromides, sulphates, carbonates, iodides of sodium, potassium, calcium and magnesium.
It contains about 3.6% metallic salts of which 2.63% is common salt.
For this reason, common salt is produced from sea water.
Water, which easily gives lather to common washing things or toilet soaps, is known as soft water.
Rain water, pond water, chemically pure water etc are soft water.
Water, which does not easily give lather to soap but does so after a considerable amount of soap is consumed, is known as hard water.
Sea water, spring or fountain water, river water, deep tube well water etc are the examples of hard water.
Soft water is most suitable for various purposes.
Rain water is the softest of all natural water.
Some substances dissolve in water to make it hard.
What substances are they?
We can do the following experiments to know the answer.
Take clear lime water or calcium hydroxide solution in a large test tube and pass carbon dioxide gas through it for 4-5 minutes.
As a result what change takes place in the lime water?
Again pass more carbon dioxide through the solution for another 3-4 minutes.
Do you observe any changes in the milky lime water now?
Yes, carbon dioxide through clear lime water produces insoluble calcium carbonate first.
As a result lime water becomes milky.
But by passing carbon dioxide for another 3-4 minutes through it, we have produced soluble calcium hydrogen carbonate and the lime water becomes clear again.
Now, mark the test tube having the solution with A.
This solution will be required for next experiment.
Take two beakers.
Take soap solution in one beaker and cool boiled water in another.
Use a dropper to put 2 cc cool boiled water in a test tube and add drops of soap solution.
After adding each drop of soap water stir the solution well.
Note down how many drops of soap solution are added.
In this way, continue adding soap solution to water with constant stirring;
a time will come when clear and bright foams will be produced.
Note down the number of drops of soap solution required to reach this stage.
Now, in another testtube, take 2 cc of solution from test tube A and add soap water solution to it drop by drop.
How many drops of soap solution are required to start foaming lather?
Do you find any distinctions between the number of drops required to make foam in boiled water and soap solution?
To make foam in solution A, more soap solution is required than that is needed in boiled water, isn't it?
Now can you tell which one is soft water and which is hard water?
From the above experiment we can say that calcium hydrogen carbonate is one of the dissolved substances in water which causes hardness of water.
Actually hardness of water may be caused by any calcium salts when dissolved in water.
Magnesium salts dissolved in water also cause hardness.
Sometimes, dissolved calcium sulphate, magnesium hydrogen carbonate and magnesium sulphate in water cause hardness of water too.
So we can say that water becomes hard due to the dissolved hydrogen carbonate, sulphate, chloride, etc. of the two metals calcium and magnesium.
Dissolved iron salts also causes hardness of water.
Sufficient amount of soap is required to wash clothes in hard water.
Soap contains sodium stearate.
Sodium stearate is soluble in water and it reacts with the dirt of clothes and cleans them.
This precipitate is suspended as a residue in water.
As a result, much soap is consumed, even there is no foam.
Calcium hydrogen sulphate reacts with sodium stearate; and after the reaction excess soap produce foam in water.
In this manner, hard water becomes soft after through the use of soap.
Have you now understood why soft water is more suitable for washing clothes than hard water?
Now, the question is how calcium hydrogen carbonate comes in water?
We know lime stone is deposited in many places in the earth.
In Bangladesh there are vast quantities of lime stone deposits in Chatak, Sylhet, St. Martin Island of Chittagong and Jaipurhat.
Lime stone is calcium carbonate.
Air contains carbon dioxide.
Now you have probably understood that how calcium hydrogen carbonates are dissolved in natural water to make it hard.
Hardness of water can be of two types Temporary hardness and Permanent hardness.
Temporary hardness is caused by the presence of the hydrogen carbonates of calcium, magnesium and iron in water.
This hardness is called temporary because it can be removed easily.
This hardness of water can be removed either by boiling water or by converting the soluble hydrogen carbonate into insoluble carbonates as precipitate.
Permanent hardness is caused by the presence of the chlorides and sulphates of calcium and magnesium in water.
This hardness of water is called permanent hardness and it cannot be removed by any easy means.
We have already learnt that hardness is caused by the presence of soluble hydrogen carbonates, chlorides and sulphates of calcium, magnesium and iron in water.
So if these soluble salts are chemically converted into insoluble salts which can be separated by filtration, then hard water will become soft.
Removal of hardness of water is called softening of water.
Temporary hardness is removed by boiling.
In this experiment some quantity of solution A of experiment no 5.1 and soap solution is required.
Besides, you will need two test tubes of the same size, candle or spirit lamp and some sodium carbonate solution.
Calcium sulphate solution and magnesium sulphate solution are also required to perform this experiment.
Take 2 ml of A solution in a test tube and 2 ml calcium sulphate in another test tube.
Boil both the solutions for 1 minute.
What is seen?
Is there any precipitate in the test tube containing solution A?
Now after cooling, put 5 drops of soap solution in each test tube and shake well.
Notice the changes in each test tube and note down in your note book.
Again take 2 ml A solution and 2 ml calcium sulphate solution in two separate test tubes.
Add 2 ml of sodium carbonate solution in both.
Do you see any changes?
Now add excess of soap solution in two test tubes and shake well.
What do you see? Write down the result in your note book.
There are two types of hardness of water.
Hardness due to the presence of soluble hydrogen carbonate can be removed by boiling.
Such type of hardness is called temporary hardness of water.
Hardness due to the presence of sulphate or chloride salts of calcium and magnesium cannot be removed by boiling.
So, heated calcium sulphate solution does not produce foam with soap solution.
This type of hardness is called permanent hardness.
Temporary and permanent both the hardness of water can be removed by sodium carbonate.
Sodium carbonate reacts with soluble calcium salt in water to produce insoluble calcium carbonate.
In this way the hardness of water is usually removed.
This process is known as soda process.
In addition to this, both permanent and temporary hardness of water can be removed by permutit process.
You will learn about this in your next classes.
Water which does not easily produce leather with soap but does so after a considerable amount of soap is consumed, is called hard water.
Water which easily produces foam with water is called soft water.
Hardness of water is caused by the presence of soluble chloride, sulphate and hydrogen carbonate of calcium, magnesium and iron in water.
Soluble calcium and magnesium salts are not present in soft water.
Household utensils are damaged by theuse of hard water.
Utensil and equipments are not damaged by the use of soft water.
Use of hard water consumes a lot of soap.
When hard water is used, insoluble heat insulator residue of calcium carbonate and calcium sulphate etc. are deposited in the boilers;
cooling chambers of motor cars and at the bottom of kettles.
This layer is insoluble and bad conductor of heat.
Due to this, heat conducting capacity of boilers decreases, which leads to misuses of fuel.
We have so far looked at some disadvantages of using hard water.
Now can you think of any possible advantages of using hard water?
Soluble salts in hard water are the constituents for building body; so hard water is suitable for health.
Calcium salt is one of the major constituents for bone and teeth.
So hard water is useful for children's bone and teeth.
Sometimes hard water acts as medicine for skin diseases, rheumatic, indigestion etc.
We have learnt about some of the disadvantages and advantages of using hard water.
The main problem to use hard water is that it consumes a lot of soap for washing clothes.
At present many cleaning agents such as detergents are available.
They work better than soap.
These are available as liquid or powder.
These cleansing agents do not react with dissolved calcium, magnesium or iron salts of hard water but form foam directly with water and clean clothes.
